item.title: ISIS Detention Camps Pose a Dangerous Problem for Syria’s Leaders
item.description: The government faces a dilemma over what to do with civil-war-era prisons and detention camps that hold thousands of ISIS fighters and tens of thousands of their family members.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Daniel Berehulak
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Agency for International Development
item.media:description: Al Hol, a detention camp in northeastern Syria, holds family members of ISIS fighters.

item.title: Venezuela’s Nobel Peace Prize Winner Raises Stakes in Stand off With Maduro
item.description: The decision by María Corina Machado, the Venezuelan opposition leader, to emerge from hiding and leave the country has electrified her movement but carries political risks.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Henrik Pryser Libell and Simon Romero
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Ana Corina Sosa, the daughter of the Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado, speaking at the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony on Wednesday in Oslo.

item.title: The Challenges to Europe’s Security Go Beyond Trump’s Lack of Support
item.description: Europeans find themselves stranded between hostile powers, Russia and the United States, with key decisions looming over the future of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A convoy of U.S. military vehicles passed through Frankenberg, Germany, en route to Poland in 2024 for NATO exercises.

item.title: Chip Company Plotted to Send Technology to China, Ex-C.E.O. Says
item.description: The former chief executive of Nexperia, a Dutch chipmaker, said Dutch officials had known for years that the company’s Chinese owner sought to move its technology to China.
item.dc:creator: Mara Hvistendahl and Joy Dong
item.media:description: On a production line of the Dutch semiconductor company Nexperia in Hamburg, Germany, last year. Dutch officials seized the company in September.

item.title: Khmer Rouge-Era Land Mines Have a Big Role in Thailand-Cambodia Conflict
item.description: Thailand says ordnance replanted by Cambodia has injured or maimed more than a dozen of its soldiers. Cambodia rejects the accusation.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: A mine clearance operation in Sisaket province in Thailand in August, near the border with Cambodia.

item.title: Danish Intelligence Report Raises Concerns About Shifts in US Policy Under Trump
item.description: A new document cites Washington’s shifting strategic priorities and growing pressure on allies under President Trump as sources of uncertainty for Denmark.
item.dc:creator: Maya Tekeli and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Cold War-era American satellite station on a hill above the settlement of Kangerlussuaq, in southwestern Greenland, in June.

item.title: UNESCO Recognizes Italian Cooking, Kohl Makeup and Icelandic Pools
item.description: The agency added dozens of nominees to its annual list of the world’s “intangible cultural heritage,” celebrating international customs and cuisine.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: Having pasta in Rome on Wednesday. The UNESCO committee said Italy’s culinary tradition “emphasizes intimacy with food, respect for ingredients and shared moments around the table.”

item.title: Louvre Heist Was Caught on Film, Officials Say, Rebutting Earlier Account
item.description: Investigators said that a security camera recorded thieves preparing to burgle the Louvre. The museum’s director said previously that the camera was facing the wrong way.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: French police officers stand next to a furniture elevator used by robbers to enter the Louvre, in October.

item.title: Yemeni Separatists Set Sights on Houthi-Controlled Capital
item.description: The Southern Transitional Council has seized control of parts of Yemen over the past week, with ambitions to create a “south Arabian state.”
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar
item.media:description: Soldiers loyal to the Southern Transitional Council, a separatist group, in Aden, Yemen, on Tuesday.

item.title: Canada’s Northwest Territories Diamond Mines Are Closing
item.description: After decades of growth driven by diamond mining, Canada’s Northwest Territories are facing the closure of three major mines and wondering: What’s next?
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Pat Kane
item.media:credit: Pat Kane for The New York Times
item.media:description: The A418 pit at the Rio Tinto Diavik Diamond Mine in Lac de Gras, Northwest Territories was closed to mining activity in 2022 and is being filled with processed kimberlite and water as part of Diavik’s agreement to remediate the landscape back to as close to its original form as possible.

item.title: With Cheap Tickets and Lax Etiquette, a Theater Builds an Older Fan Base
item.description: The Hollywood Classic cinema in Seoul is popular in a country where 70-year-olds now outnumber people in their 20s.
item.dc:creator: Max Kim and Woohae Cho
item.media:description: The ticket booth at the Hollywood Classic cinema in Seoul, the capital of South Korea, in November.

item.title: Lithuania Declares National Emergency Over Suspicious Balloons From Belarus
item.description: Hundreds of weather balloons sent to Lithuania this year have disrupted flights and stirred alarm in a sabotage campaign against a NATO state.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: State Border Guard Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An officer inspecting a balloon used to carry cigarettes into Lithuania.

item.title: Australia’s Social Media Ban for Children Takes Effect
item.description: The measure, which affects anyone under 16, is one of the most sweeping efforts in the world to safeguard young people from the potential harms of the platforms.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Australia’s Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, center, standing alongside 12-year-old girl Flossie, center left, who criticized social media companies during an official function to mark the start of Australia’s social media changes in Sydney on Wednesday.

item.title: Israeli Ban on Media Entering Gaza Remains, as Legal Challenge Is Delayed
item.description: Israel’s top court gave the government further reprieve on a long-stalled petition seeking free access to Gaza. Critics say barring journalists denies the world a full picture of conditions there.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction in Jabaliya, northeast of Gaza City, in November.

item.title: Mexico Approves 50% Tariffs on Many Chinese Imports
item.description: The tariffs will apply to goods from China and other nations. Washington has been pressuring Mexico to move away from dealing with China.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and James Wagner
item.media:description: A display of cars by the Chinese automaker BYD in the Mexican city of Ciudad Juarez. China is the second largest exporter to Mexico after the United States.

item.title: Former King Juan Carlos I of Spain, Seeking Relevance, Publishes Book
item.description: King Juan Carlos I of Spain abdicated and left for exile years ago. Now, his attempted comeback is giving his family a royal headache.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.media:description: Juan Carlos I of Spain, in February. He has been mostly left out of recent celebrations of the 50th anniversary of Spain’s transition to democracy, in which he was instrumental.

item.title: María Corina Machado Appears in Norway After Missing Nobel Ceremony
item.description: María Corina Machado, who spent over a year in hiding in Venezuela, greeted supporters in Oslo, hours after her daughter accepted the Nobel Peace Prize in her name.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Jonas Been Henriksen/NTB Scanpix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: María Corina Machado greeting supporters in Oslo from a hotel balcony early on Thursday morning.

item.title: Britain Releases New Data on ‘Grooming Gangs’ and Child Sexual Abuse
item.description: The police in Britain warned that the threat from online predators has been rising while political attention has been focused elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood has called for a “moment of reckoning” in the inquiry into child sexual abuse in Britain.

item.title: Lawsuit Challenges Park Service Passes Featuring Trump
item.description: An environmental group is suing, saying federal law requires an image of public lands, not the president.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow

item.title: M23 Rebels Seize Uvira in Eastern Congo
item.description: The fighting in Congo continues despite Washington’s claims to have brokered an end to the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Saikou Jammeh and Ruth Maclean
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: With the capture of Uvira, the militia M23 now controls both the North and South Kivu regions in eastern Congo.

item.title: A Controversial Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: The Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado supports the use of force to overthrow her country’s government.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado in Caracas after voting in the presidential election last year.

item.title: Trump Says U.S. Seized Oil Tanker Off Venezuelan Coast
item.description: The seizure comes as the United States builds up its forces in the Caribbean as part of a campaign against President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Eric Schmitt and Nicholas Nehamas
item.media:description: President Trump announced the seizure at the White House on Wednesday, without giving details on the operation.

item.title: How Andrew Tate, Manosphere Star Accused of Rape and Trafficking, Was Freed
item.description: Barred from leaving Romania, Andrew Tate courted powerful figures on the American right, from Tucker Carlson to Barron Trump. Then an extraordinary order let him go.
item.dc:creator: Megan Twohey and Isabella Kwai

item.title: Inside the Pentagon’s Scramble to Deal With Boat Strike Survivors
item.description: Officials initially weighed sending survivors of U.S. attacks on boats suspected of drug smuggling to a notorious prison in El Salvador, to keep them away from American courts.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave, Edward Wong and Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Recent news reports on strike orders given by Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth have raised questions of potential war crimes.

item.title: Kirsten Hillman, Canada’s Ambassador to U.S., to Leave Post
item.description: Kirsten Hillman, who came to Washington during the first Trump administration, had already extended her tenure once.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Justin Tang/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kirsten Hillman did not specify a date for the end of her tenure but said that after she leaves, she will still be available to Canada’s negotiators.

item.title: Ukraine Could Be ‘Ready for Elections,’ Zelensky Says
item.description: The Ukrainian president told reporters that a vote could be held in 60 to 90 days if the country received security protections from the United States.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine speaking at the White House in Washington, D.C., in October.

item.title: U.S. Plans to Scrutinize 5 Years of Social Media History for Foreign Tourists
item.description: Even visitors from countries like Britain and France, whose citizens don’t need visas, would have to share five years’ worth of social media.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:description: Visitors from countries in the visa waiver program would also be required to share a range of other information, including email addresses from the last decade.

item.title: Seattle’s Plans for a Pride Match at World Cup Infuriates Iran and Egypt
item.description: The two countries, which criminalize homosexuality and impose severe punishments for it, were picked to play on a day celebrating L.G.B.T.Q. communities.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Iran learned its group at the FIFA World Cup draw last week in Washington, D.C.

item.title: For Real, a Natural History of Misinformation
item.description: It’s not just humans who suffer from leading one another astray. So do fish, flies and even bacteria.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Rob Stewart/Image Bank Film, via Getty Images

item.title: Nobel Peace Prize for Venezuela’s María Corina Machado Draws Criticism
item.description: María Corina Machado is being honored for her push for democracy even as she backs President Trump’s military buildup and aggressive campaign against Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The opposition leader María Corina Machado in her office in Caracas last year.

item.title: Trump and Europe’s Far Right
item.description: The American national security strategy echoes the language of far-right parties. But hardliners across the Atlantic seem unimpressed.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Canada Plans to Fast-Track Immigration for US H1-B Visa Holders in New Talent Drive
item.description: The government says it will fast-track immigration for U.S. H-1B visa holders and spend more than $1 billion to attract researchers from the United States and the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: The University of Toronto, one of the world’s best-ranked academic institutions, picked up several top professors from Ivy League schools this year, including two from M.I.T.

item.title: Brigitte Macron’s Slur Against Feminist Protesters Prompts an Outcry in France
item.description: Brigitte Macron used a slur to criticize protesters who had interrupted a show by a French comedian accused of rape in 2021, in a case that was dismissed.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: Brigitte Macron, wife of President Emmanuel Macron of France, jokingly vowed to protect the comedian from the protesters, and used a slur, a video showed.

item.title: Staying Informed and Not Overwhelmed in 2026
item.description: We are asking readers to share their tips for coping with the news.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: The Territorial Sticking Point Between Russia and Ukraine
item.description: The Kremlin says any peace deal must cede to Russia the entire eastern Donbas region, including territory Ukraine still controls — a nonstarter for Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Josh Holder

item.title: A History of U.S. Military Action in Latin America
item.description: The United States’ history in the region includes several about-faces, contradictions and missteps.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: HUM Images/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: U.S. troops in Veracruz, Mexico, in April 1914, as part of a blockade of the city’s port.

item.title: Iain Douglas-Hamilton, Who Studied, and Protected, Elephants, Dies at 83
item.description: Born into an aristocratic British family, he turned his empathy and knowledge of the world’s largest land mammals to the cause of saving them from poachers.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman

item.title: The Conflict Over Nigeria’s Returned Treasures
item.description: Western museums are returning the Benin Bronzes — priceless items looted during colonialism — to Nigeria, but political infighting has jeopardized the ability to display and maintain the masterpieces. Our reporter, Alex Marshall, traveled to Nigeria to see some of the Bronzes.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall, Stephen Tayo, Nikolay Nikolov and Christina Thornell

item.title: Another Front in the War in Ukraine: Who Gets to Claim a Famed Artist?
item.description: Looking to shake off Moscow’s cultural influences, Kyiv has been seeking to highlight the Ukrainian roots of Kazimir Malevich, a renowned avant-garde painter.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: Destruction of Cultural Antiquities and Heritage
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: A train car dedicated to Kazimir Malevich in Kyiv, Ukraine, in October.

item.title: All 187,460 Miles of Road That Led to Rome, Mapped
item.description: A digital atlas of ancient Rome’s highways and byways reveals a road network that was more extensive than thought.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz

item.title: Hundreds of Thousands of Thais and Cambodians Flee
item.description: People escaped from a deadly border conflict, the authorities said, with some sheltering at a racetrack in Thailand and others near temples in Cambodia.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: A Thai resident who fled clashes between Thai and Cambodian soldiers, using a cellphone while taking shelter in Buriram Province, Thailand, on Tuesday.

item.title: Between Pakistan and Afghanistan, a Trade War With No End in Sight
item.description: After deadly cross-border military clashes, the Pakistani and Afghan governments have locked their populations in a trade war threatening the livelihoods of millions.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:credit: Asim Hafeez for The New York Times

item.title: Honduras Issues Arrest Warrant for Hernández, Ex-President Pardoned by Trump
item.description: The attorney general said he had asked Interpol to detain Juan Orlando Hernández, who was freed from a U.S. prison last week.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:description: Juan Orlando Hernández was president of Honduras from 2014 to 2022 and was convicted on drug-trafficking charges in the United States last year.

item.title: Russian Court Sentences 4 Soldiers to Prison for Killing Texan
item.description: Russell Bonner Bentley III, 64, who was living in the occupied Donbas region of Ukraine, was beaten and tortured to death after he was suspected of being an American saboteur, investigators said.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Russell Bonner Bentley III visiting a memorial to victims of Nazi killings, in Donetsk, Ukraine, in 2017.

item.title: The Second ‘China Shock’
item.description: Chinese exports are flooding the developing world, and the social consequences are bound to be profound.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Geely manufacturing plant in Hangzhou, China.

item.title: Jerusalem Authorities Raid UNRWA Compound and Raise Israeli Flag
item.description: Municipal officials say the action was about unpaid taxes. The U.N. relief agency for Palestinians says it is exempt from taxes and should be immune from such a raid, calling it illegal.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: An Israeli flag being raised on the roof of an UNRWA building in East Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: Collector Surrenders ‘Nude Emperor’ Statue Identified as Looted
item.description: The statue and a marble head of a Greek orator seized from the Met Museum were among dozens of items found to have been looted that were handed over to Turkey at a ceremony in Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg and Graham Bowley

item.title: Attacks on Kindergarten and Hospital Kill 114 in Sudan, W.H.O. Says
item.description: The drone strikes were blamed on the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces, extending a pattern of atrocities in Sudan’s 2½-year civil war.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce and Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Woman displaced following the capture of El Fasher waiting to receive aid at a camp in Al Dabbah, Sudan, in November.

item.title: One Hundred Schoolchildren Released After Kidnapping in Nigeria
item.description: The abduction of over 260 children from a Catholic school last month was the latest in a recent spate of kidnappings in the country.
item.dc:creator: Saikou Jammeh and Ismail Alfa
item.media:credit: Ifeanyi Immanuel Bakwenye/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A classroom at St. Mary’s Catholic boarding school in Niger State, Nigeria, last month following the kidnapping.

item.title: Why Russian Spies Are Using Mexico to Target the U.S.
item.description: American officials pleaded with Mexico to expel two dozen Russian spies posing as diplomats operating in Mexico. Their concerns were dismissed.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists on the beach in Cancun, Mexico, in November. U.S. officials worry that among those vacationing are spies working for Moscow.

item.title: The U.S. Gave Mexico a List of Russian Spies. Mexico Let Them Stay.
item.description: Moscow has ramped up covert operations in Mexico, with spies meeting handlers in its bustling capital and seaside resorts, U.S. officials say.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Russian Embassy in Mexico City is one of Moscow’s largest around the world, according to its Foreign Ministry, although the Kremlin and Mexico have few economic, cultural or military ties.

item.title: Why Thailand and Cambodia Are Fighting
item.description: The latest violence comes months after President Trump helped mediate a cease-fire between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Sarot Meksophawannakul/Thai News Pix, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Families gathered at a temporary shelter in Buriram province, Thailand, on Monday after clashes along the Thailand-Cambodia border.

item.title: 7.6-Magnitude Earthquake Near Japan Triggers Tsunami Warning
item.description: The 7.6-magnitude quake struck in waters off Aomori Prefecture on Japan’s main island, Honshu. It triggered a tsunami warning, which was later lifted.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser, Hisako Ueno and Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: A vehicle on a collapsed section of road in Tohoku Town, Japan, on Tuesday.
